member.summary: Determines if CoherentFlexCel will automatically delete existing files or not.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.ResetCellSelections
member.summary: When true, all sheets will selections will be reset to A1. This way, you do not need to care about setting the correct selection when editing the template.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.HtmlMode
member.summary:
When true, CoherentFlexCel will interpret the text as HTML, and honor the tags that it can understand. Note that when in HtmlMode, many consecutive spaces will be interpreted as one, and carriage returns will be interpreted as spaces. To enter real carriage returns you need to enter a
tag (unless the text is inside 
 tags). 
            Also & symbols need to be escaped. For more info on HTML syntax supported, see 
            
Note that the <#HTML> tag can overwrite the Html behavior on a cell by cell basis.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.DisableSQLValidation
member.summary: If false (the default) CoherentFlexCelReport will only allow DirectSQL queries that begin with "SELECT", to avoid people doing inserts or deletes from the config sheet. If true, CoherentFlexCelReport will pass the DirectSQL queries you write in the config sheet directly to the server. Caution: Setting this property to true might have security implications. Take a look at the remarks.
member.remarks:
You can disable the SQL validation if for example you want to read data from stored procedures in SQL Server. While most databases will allow you to do a Select from a stored procedure, in SQL server you'll need to call "EXEC". For example:
sql(conn; exec GetOrders)
But note that if you disable SQL validation, you'll be letting the user run any arbitrary stored procedure in the server, or insert, update or delete records. In both cases, either with SQL validation true or false, you'll want to give the users a readonly connection with permissions only to the objects they need so they can't modify stuff in the database with the template. But if you disable SQL validation, then there is one less barrier to users modifying data in the database from the report.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.EnterFormulas
member.summary: When true, CoherentFlexCel will try to enter any string starting with "=" as a formula instead of text. If this property is true, any string you enter that starts with "=" must be a valid formula, or an error will be raised. When you know a priori which cells will have formulas, you might want to use the <#formula> tag instead.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.TryToConvertStrings
member.summary:
When true, CoherentFlexCel will try to convert strings to numbers or dates before entering them into the cells. USE THIS PROPERTY WITH CARE! You shouldn't normally need to use this property, since CoherentFlexCel automatically enters numbers or dates in the DataSets as number or dates in the Excel file. If you need to use this property, it means that data in your database is stored as strings when they should not be. So the correct fix is to fix the columns you know should have numbers to have numbers, NOT to use this property. This is just a workaround when you can't do anything else about it.
Note also that this method is not efficient since it has to "guess" what a string might be if anything, and it might be wrong. Also, it might have issues with locales: Does the string "1/2/2008" means January 2 or February 1? Depends on the locale.
member.remarks: If you have a single field which is a string but you want converted, you can write <#evaluate(VALUE(<#db.StringValue>))> in the cell you want converted and keep this property false.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.ExpressionRecursionLimit
member.summary: Defines how much nesting you can have in Expressions before CoherentFlexCel throws an error. You might have an expression like <#A> which is defined based in another expression <#B> which in turn is defined based in another one that finally might come back to <#A> As it is not possible for CoherentFlexCel to know if the recursion will finish or loop forever, it will try until it reaches the limit you set here. Note that a too big limit could cause a stack overflow.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.RecalcMode
member.summary: Determines if the report will be recalculated before saving. See for more info.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.RecalcVersion
member.summary: Before changing this property, look at Determines if the formulas will be recalculated when Excel opens them.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.ErrorActions
member.summary: Determines if CoherentFlexCel will throw Exceptions or just ignore errors on specific situations. When the errors are ignored, they will be logged into the class.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.ErrorsInResultFile
member.summary:
When true and there is an error reading cells in the template or writing the cells in the report, the error message will be written in the corresponding cell on the generated report. No Exception will be thrown.
You can use this property to DEBUG reports, as it provides an easy way to see all errors at once in the place they are produced. But is it recommended that you leave this property FALSE in production, or you could create xls files with error messages inside. See also
member.remarks: You can also set this property in the template, by writing <#ErrorsInResultFile> in the expressions column in the config sheet.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.DebugExpressions
member.summary: Set this value to true if you want to analyze how CoherentFlexCel is evaluating the tags in a file. When true, a full stack trace will be written in the cell instead of the tag values. See for information on how to use those stack traces.
member.remarks: You can also set this property in the template, by writing <#Debug> in the expressions column in the config sheet. Debug in the template will set both this property and to true.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.DebugIntelligentPageBreaks
member.summary: Set this value to true if you want to analyze how CoherentFlexCel is setting up the intelligent page breaks. When this property is true, CoherentFlexCel will add one row at the top of the spreadsheet (if the sheet has keeptogether column ranges), and one column at the left of the spreadsheet (if the sheet has keeptogether row ranges). This row and column will show the levels of keeptogether in the respective column and row. See for more information.
member.remarks: You can also set this property in the template, by writing <#Debug Intelligent Page Breaks> in the expressions column in the config sheet.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.SqlParameterReplace
member.summary: Format string for replacing the standard parameter names on DIRECT SQL commands. You can leave it empty for ODBC, OLEDB or SQLSERVER databases. See Also
member.remarks: On ADO.NET sql parameters can be defined on multiple ways, depending on the database you use. For example, SQL Server will use "@ParamName", while OLEDB will use "?" as parameter id. But, to keep templates database independent, you will always use "@ParamName" notation on the Direct SQL commands you write on templates. When using OLEDB, ODBC or SqlSever, CoherentFlexCel knows how to replace the correct parameters on the SQL on templates, but for more generic databases you might need to use this property. This is a standard .NET format string, where {0} will be replaced by the parameter name. For example, on Oracle database you might need to set this value to ":{0}" (without quotes) that will translate on ":ParamName"
member.example: On oracle databases, you can set this property to ":{0}" (without quotes) It will create parameters of type ":ParamName".

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.SqlParametersType
member.summary: Type of parameters for the database. Positional parameters are the ones where you write "?" on the sql, and positional are when you write a name, like "@employee" or ":orderid". See Also

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.SemiAbsoluteReferences
member.summary: When this property is set to true, absolute references to cells inside bands being copied will be treated as relative. This way, if you have "=$A$1" inside a band and cell A1 is also inside the band, it will change to A2,A3..etc when the band is copied down. This can be useful in a master-detail report, where you want the cells in the detail to point to a fixed cell inside every record of the master. See for more information.
member.remarks: You can also set this property in the template, by writing <#Semi Absolute References> or <#Absolute References> in the expressions column in the config sheet.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.CoherentFlexCelReport.UseLegacyLookup
member.summary: When true, CoherentFlexCel will use DataViews to do lookups in DataSets, instead of using its own internal lookup algorithm. Only set this property to true if you have legacy reports that break when you use the internal lookup algorithm, because they depended in bugs in the DataView lookup implementation. For all new code, keep this property false.

member.name: T:CoherentFlexCel.Report.TCoherentFlexCelUserFunction
member.summary: A class used to define a CoherentFlexCel user function, that you can call from a report.
member.remarks:
To Create a User function:
Create a new class derived from TCoherentFlexCelUserFunction.
Override the method .
Add the new user function to the report using .
member.example:
To define an user function that returns "One" for param = 1; "Two" for param = 2 and "Unknown" on any other case: 1) Define the class:
2) Add the function to the report.
3) Now, you can write "<#MF(1)>" on a template, and it will be replaced by "One".

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.TCoherentFlexCelUserFunction.Evaluate(System.Object[])
member.summary: Override this method on a derived class to implement your own defined function.
member.param: An array of objects.
member.returns: The derived class should return the value of the function on the return parameter.

member.name: T:CoherentFlexCel.Report.TCoherentFlexCelUserFormat
member.summary: A class used to define a cell format in code, that you can call from a report.
member.remarks:
To Create a User format:
Create a new class derived from TCoherentFlexCelUserFormat.
Override the method .
Add the new user format to the report using .
member.example:
To define a user format that will format the cell according to the first parameter you pass to the function, you would: 1) Define the class:
2) Add the function to the report.
3) Now, you can write "<#format cell(MFMT;255)>" on a cell in the template, and it will painted blue.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.TCoherentFlexCelUserFormat.Evaluate(CoherentFlexCel.Core.ExcelFile,CoherentFlexCel.Core.TXlsCellRange,System.Object[])
member.summary: Override this method on a derived class to implement your own defined function.
member.param: File where we are setting the format.
Range of cells being formatted. Note that it might be a full row or column if using Format Row or Format Column.
An array of objects.
member.returns: The derived class should return the value of the function on the return parameter.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.#ctor(System.String,CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable)
member.summary: Creates a new virtual datatable instance and assigns a name to it.
member.param: Name for the virtual data table. Note that this name is *not* used anywhere in CoherentFlexCel code, except to report errors. The Table names that are used on reports are the ones in
Table that created this table (via a filter, distinct, etc), or null if this table wasn't created from another VirtualDataTable.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.TableName
member.summary: Name for the virtual data table. Note that this name is *not* used anywhere in CoherentFlexCel code, except to report errors. The Table names that are used on reports are the ones in

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.Locale
member.summary: Locale for this dataset. This might be needed to create datatables with data and the same locale.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.CreateState(System.String,CoherentFlexCel.Report.TMasterDetailLink[],CoherentFlexCel.Report.TSplitLink)
member.summary: Creates a VirtualDataSetState to be used in a report. Make sure you override this method on your derived classes and point it to the correct VirtualDataSet descendant.
member.param: A string showing how to sort this dataset. This string might be null, empty, or whatever the user wrote on the config sheet.

A list of the the master datatables and relation fields on the bands outside this one. You can pass this parameter to the VirtualDataSetState so it can create indexes on the required fields. This parameter will be an empty array if no master detail relationships apply to the VirtualDataSetState, but it will not be null.
A link to a parent Split datasource with the number of records to split, or null if there is no parent split datasource.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.ColumnCount
member.summary: Returns the number of columns of the table.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.FullDataSetColumnCount
member.summary: Returns the columns in the table for a full dataset. Normally this is the same as but your implementation might choose to hide some of the fields available in the full ColumnCount when dumping all fields. If you change this method, you need also to review so it returns the correct column for the dataset.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.GetFullDataSetColumn(System.Int32)
member.summary: Maps a normal column to a Full Dataset column, in case you aren't outputting the same fields for full datasets as the fields available for a report. If you are outputting all the fields, then this returns Column.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.GetColumn(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a column indentifier that you can later use on . Return -1 if the column does not exist, and make sure this search is case insensitive.
member.param: Name of the column to search.
member.returns: Column identifier if found, -1 if not found.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.GetColumnName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the column name for a column identifier. This method is the reverse of
member.param: Column index returned by
member.returns: The name of the column at columnIndex. If the columnIndex is not valid it should throw an Exception, since this method will only be called for columnIndexes returned by

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.GetColumnCaption(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the column caption for a column identifier. This method is used on generic dataset to write the header column. For most uses, will be used.
member.param: Column index returned by
member.returns: The name of the column at columnIndex. If the columnIndex is not valid it should throw an Exception, since this method will only be called for columnIndexes returned by

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.FilterData(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This method should return a new VirtualDataTable instance with the data filtered. If RowFilter is null, this method should return a copy of the dataset with a different name. Note that you might have the same data with different states, so this method might be called more than once.
member.remarks: You do not need to implement this method if you do not want to let users create new filtered datasets on the config sheet.
member.param: How this new VirtualDataSet will be named. This is what the user wrote on the config sheet, when creating a filtered dataset. Note that as with all the VirtualDataSets, this name is meaningless except for error messages.

Filter for the new data. This can be null, an empty string, or whatever the user wrote on the "filter" column on the config sheet. Note that if the Filter is "distinct()" this method will not be called, but instead. This method will not be called if the filter is "Split()" either.
member.returns: A new VirtualDataTable with the filtered data and the new name.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.GetDistinct(System.String,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Override this method to return a new VirtualDataSet with unique values. Note that the returned dataset will not have all the columns this one has, only the ones defined on "filterFields"
member.remarks: You do not need to implement this method if you do not want to let users create "Distinct()" filters on the config sheet.
member.param: How this new VirtualDataSet will be named. This is what the user wrote on the config sheet, when creating the distinct dataset. Note that as with all the VirtualDataSets, this name is meaningless except for error messages.
Fields where to apply the "distinct" condition.
member.returns: A new VirtualDataTable with the filtered data and the new name.

member.summary: Override this method if the table has linked tables that you can use for master detail relationships instead of normal relationships. This is the case for example in Entity Framework.
member.param: Name of the detail dataset we are looking for.
Detail dataset that we are looking for.
member.returns: The dataset if it is a detail dataset, null otherwise.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.GetRelationWith(CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable)
member.summary: Override this method if the datatable has intrinsic relationships that you want to use. For example DataSets have DataRelationships, or Entity Framework tables are related as properties from the master to the detail. All those relationships that are not explicitly defined in the report should be returned here.
member.param: Detail table from where we want to get the relationship.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.CreatedBy
member.summary: Returns the table that created this one (by a filter, distinct, etc), or null if this table was not created from another VirtualDataTable.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTable.Lookup(CoherentFlexCel.Report.TLookupFieldDefinition,System.Object[],System.String)
member.summary: Looks for a key on this dataset and returns the corresponding value. Note: Remember that VirtualDataSet is stateless, so if you use any caching here, make sure you appropiately lock() this method so there is no possibility of one thread reading the cache when the other is updating it.
member.remarks: You do not need to implement this method unless you want to provide an optimized routine. There is a default implementation which will look at all the records, cache them in a hash table, and use that for lookup. This default implementation should be enough in most cases.
member.param: Fields used to do the lookup.
A list of the values for the keys, that you should use to locate the right record.
How the data is sorted. This is relevant for TOP tables where not all data is available.
member.returns: The value at "column" , for the record where the columns on "keyNames" have the "keyValues" values. If there is more than one record where "keyNames" is equal to "keyValues" you might opt to throw an Exception or just return any of the valid values, depending on the behavior you want for lookup.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTableState.TryAggregate(CoherentFlexCel.Report.TAggregateType,System.Int32,System.Object@)
member.summary: This method is used by the "AGGREGATE" tag in a CoherentFlexCel report to calculate the maximum/minimum/average/etc of the values in the table. If you don't implement this method, CoherentFlexCel will still calculate those values by looping through the dataset, but if you have a faster way to do it (like with a "select max(field) from table") then implement this method and return true.
member.param: Which operation to do on the dataset. (Max/Min/etc)
Index of the field in which we want to aggregate.
Returns the result of the operation in the dataset. It should be null, a double or a datetime.
member.returns: True if this method is implemented, false if not. Note that even if we return false here, CoherentFlexCel will still calculate the aggregate by looping through all the records.

member.name: P:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTableState.RowCount
member.summary: Returns the number of rows available on the dataset, for the current state. Note that this method can be called many times, so it should be fast. Use a cache if necessary. Do *not* use something like "return select count(*) from table" here, it would be too slow.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTableState.Eof
member.summary: This method returns if we have reached the last record in the table. The default implementation just sees if = . If RowCount is slow and you have a faster way to know if you are at the end, override this method.
member.returns: True if we are at the end of the datatable.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTableState.MoveMasterRecord(CoherentFlexCel.Report.TMasterDetailLink[],CoherentFlexCel.Report.TSplitLink)
member.summary: This method will be called each time that the master datasource moves its position. Use it to filter the data returned if this is used on a master-detail relationship.
member.remarks: You do not need to implement this method if you are not using Master-Detail or Split relationships.
member.param: List of all the master tables that are related to this one. If there are no parents on this VirtualDataTableState, this will be an empty array, not null. Use it on to filter the data and then return only the records that satisfy the master-detail relationships on

Parent Split table if this dataset is on a Split relationship, or null if there is none. Use it to know how many records you should retun on . Note that a table might be on Master-Detail relationship *and* split relationship. In this case you need to first filter the records that are on the master detail relationship, and then apply the split to them.

member.name: M:CoherentFlexCel.Report.VirtualDataTableState.FilteredRowCount(CoherentFlexCel.Report.TMasterDetailLink[])
member.summary: This method will be called when a Split master wants to know how many records its detail has. For example, if the detail has 30 records and the split is at 10, the Split master will call this method to find out that it has to return 3 on its own record count. You need to filter the data here depending on the master detail relationships, but not on the splitLink.
member.remarks: You do not need to implement this method if you are not using Split relationships.
member.param: List of all the master tables that are related to this one. If there are no parents on this VirtualDataTableState, this will be an empty array, not null.
member.returns: The count of records for a specific position of the master datasets.
